examples: Lurgashall English Mead, Redstone Traditional Mountain Honey Wine, Sky River Semi-Sweet Mead, Intermiel Verge d’Or and Mélilot

name: Sweet Mead
description: Similar in balance, body, finish and flavor intensity to a dry white wine, with a pleasant mixture of subtle honey character, soft fruity esters, and clean alcohol.  Complexity, harmony, and balance of sensory elements are most desirable, with no inconsistencies in color, aroma, flavor or aftertaste.  The proper balance of sweetness, acidity, alcohol, and honey character is the essential final measure of any mead.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. Traditional Meads feature the character of a blended honey or a blend of honeys.  Varietal meads feature the distinctive character of certain honeys. Show meads feature no additives, but this distinction is usually not obvious to judges.
examples: Moonlight Sensual, Lurgashall Christmas Mead, Chaucer’s Mead, Rabbit’s Foot Sweet Wildflower Honey Mead, Intermiel Benoîte

name: Cyser
description: A cyser is a melomel made with apples, generally cider.  In well-made examples of the style, the fruit is both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honeysweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Some of the best strong examples have the taste and aroma of an aged Calvados (apple brandy from northern France), while subtle, dry versions can taste similar to many fine white wines. There should be an appealing blend of the fruit and honey character but not necessarily an even balance. Generally a good tannin-sweetness balance is desired, though very dry and very sweet examples do exist.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. Cyser is a mead made with the addition of apples or apple juice. Traditionally, cysers are made by the addition of honey to apple juice without additional water.
examples: Moonlight Blossom, White Winter Cyser, Rabbit’s Foot Apple Cyser

name: Pyment
description: A pyment is a melomel made with grapes, generally from juice.  Just as with wines, pyments can be red, white, or blush.  In well-made examples of the style, the grape is both distinctively vinous and well-incorporated into the honey-sweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. White and red versions can be quite different, and the overall impression should be characteristic of the type of grapes used and suggestive of a similar variety wine. There should be an appealing blend of the fruit and honey character but not necessarily an even balance. Generally a good tannin-sweetness balance is desired, though very dry and very sweet examples do exist.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. Cyser is a mead made with the addition of apples or apple juice. Traditionally, cysers are made by the addition of honey to apple juice without additional water.
examples: Celestial Meads Que Syrah, Moonlight Slow Dance, Redstone Pinot Noir and White Pyment Mountain Honey Wines

name: Berry Mead
description: Berries can have seeds, but do not have stones/pits; some are aggregates of druplets.  Combinations of berries can be entered here. The culinary, not botanical, definition of berry is used here. If you have to justify a fruit using the word “technically” as part of the description, then that’s not what we mean.  In well-made examples of the style, the fruit is both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honeysweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Different types of fruit can result in widely different characteristics; allow for a variation in the final product.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. A berry mead is a mead made with the addition of other berries or berry juices, including a blend of berries. There should be an appealing blend of the fruit and honey character but not necessarily an even balance.
examples: Moonlight Blissful, Wild, Caress, and Mischief, White Winter Blueberry, Raspberry and Strawberry Melomels, Celestial Meads Miel Noir, Redstone Black Raspberry Nectar, Bees Brothers Raspberry Mead, Intermiel Honey Wine and Raspberries, Honey Wine and Blueberries, and Honey Wine and Blackcurrants, Mountain Meadows Cranberry Mead

name: Stone Fruit Mead
description: A Stone Fruit Mead is an entry category for melomels made with stone fruit, such as cherries, plums, peaches, apricots, and mangoes. Stone fruit are fleshy fruit with a single large pit or stone. The culinary, not botanical, definition of stone fruit is used here. If you have to justify a fruit using the word “technically” as part of the description, then that’s not what we mean. Combinations of stone fruit can be entered here.  In well-made examples of the style, the fruit is both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honeysweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Different types of fruit can result in widely different characteristics; allow for a variation in the final product.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. A stone fruit mead is a mead made with the addition of other stone fruit or stone fruit juices. There should be an appealing blend of the fruit and honey character but not necessarily an even balance. A stone fruit mead can be made with a blend of stone fruits, but not other fruit not allowable in this category.
examples: Mountain Meadows Cherry Mead, Moonlight Entice, Sumptuous, Flirt, and Smitten, Redstone Sunshine Nectar

name: Melomel
description: The melomel subcategory is for fruit meads made with any fruit not associated with any other fruit mead subcategory, or with a combination of fruits from multiple fruit mead subcategories (such as grapes and stone fruit). If in doubt, enter the fruit here – judges should be flexible with fruit not explicitly named in other categories. The culinary, not botanical, definition of fruit is used here. If you have to justify a fruit using the word “technically” as part of the description, then that’s not what we mean.  In well-made examples of the style, the fruit is both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honeysweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Different types of fruit can result in widely different characteristics; allow for a variation in the final product.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. A melomel is a mead made with the addition of other fruit or fruit juices not specifically reserved for other entry subcategories. There should be an appealing blend of the fruit and honey character but not necessarily an even balance. A melomel can be made with a blend of fruits from multiple Fruit Mead subcategories.
examples: Moonlight Desire, Paramour, and Iniquity

name: Fruit and Spice Mead
description: A Fruit and Spice Mead is a mead containing one or more fruits and one or more spices. See the definitions of fruit used in the various Fruit Mead subcategories; any ingredient qualifying there meets the “fruit” requirement here. For purposes of this subcategory, any ingredient qualifying for use in the Spice, Herb, or Vegetable Mead subcategory also meets the “spice” requirement here.  In well-made examples of the style, the fruits and spices are both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honey-sweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Different types of fruits and spices can result in widely different characteristics; allow for significant variation in the final product.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. See the various Fruit Mead descriptions, as well as the Spice, Herb, or Vegetable Mead description for additional details.
examples: Moonlight Kurt’s Apple Pie, Mojo, Flame, Fling, and Deviant, Celestial Meads Scheherazade, Rabbit’s Foot Private Reserve Pear Mead, Intermiel Rosée

name: Spice, Herb Or Vegetable Mead
description: A Spice, Herb, or Vegetable Mead contains one or more spices, herbs, or vegetables (in this style definition, these are collectively known as “spices”). The culinary, not botanical, definition of spice, herb, or vegetable is used here. If you have to justify a spice, herb, or vegetable using the word “technically” as part of the description, then that’s not what we mean. The same definitions apply to this category as to the similarly named beer category. In addition to the more obvious spices, herbs, and vegetables that fit into this subcategory, the following ingredients also are explicitly included: roses, rose hips, ginger, rhubarb, pumpkins, chile peppers, coffee, chocolate, nuts (including coconut), citrus peels/zest, and teas (except those strictly used for increasing tannin levels, not for adding flavor).  In well-made examples of the style, the spices are both distinctive and well-incorporated into the honeysweet-acid-tannin-alcohol balance of the mead. Different types of spices can result in widely different characteristics; allow for a variation in the final product.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Standard description applies. If spices are used in conjunction with other ingredients such as fruit, cider, or other fruit-based fermentables, then the mead should be entered as a Fruit and Spice Mead. If spices are used in combination with other ingredients, then the mead should be entered as an Experimental Mead.
examples: Moonlight Wicked, Breathless, Madagascar, and Seduction, Redstone Vanilla Beans and Cinnamon Sticks Mountain Honey Wine, Bonair Chili Mead, Redstone Juniper Mountain Honey Wine, iQhilika Africa Birds Eye Chili Mead, Mountain Meadows Spice Nectar

name: Braggot
description: A Braggot is a mead made with malt.  A harmonious blend of mead and beer, with the distinctive characteristics of both. A wide range of results are possible, depending on the base style of beer, variety of honey and overall sweetness and strength. Beer flavors tend to somewhat mask typical honey flavors found in other meads.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: A braggot is a mead made with both honey and malt providing flavor and fermentable extract. Originally, and alternatively, a mixture of mead and ale. A braggot can be made with any type of honey, and any type of base beer style. The malt component may be derived from grain or malt extracts. The beer may be hopped or not. If any other ingredients than honey and beer are contained in the braggot, it should be entered as an Experimental Mead. Smoked braggots may be entered in this category if using smoked malt or a smoked beer as the base style; braggots made using other smoked ingredients (e.g., liquid smoke, chipotles) should be entered in the Experimental Mead style.
examples: Rabbit’s Foot Diabhal and Bière de Miele, Magic Hat Braggot, Brother Adams Braggot Barleywine Ale, White Winter Traditional Brackett

name: Historical Mead
description: A Historical Mead is a historical or indigenous mead that doesn’t fit into another subcategory (e.g., Ethiopian tej, Polish meads). The BJCP welcomes submissions of writeups of historical or indigenous styles that fit into this category.  This mead should exhibit the character of all of the ingredients in varying degrees, and should show a good blending or balance between the various flavor elements.  Whatever ingredients are included, the result should be identifiable as a honey-based fermented beverage.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
examples: Jadwiga, Saba Tej

name: Experimental Mead
description: An Experimental Mead is a mead that does not fit into any other mead subcategory. This could apply to meads that blend multiple mead subcategories (unless the combination fits elsewhere, such as Melomel or Fruit and Spice Mead). Any experimental mead using additional sources of fermentables (e.g., maple syrup, molasses, brown sugar, or agave nectar), additional ingredients (e.g., liquors, smoke, etc.), alternative processes (e.g., icing), fermentation with non-traditional yeasts (e.g., Brettanomyces, Belgian lambic or ale, etc.), or other unusual ingredient, process, or technique would also be appropriate in this category. Oak-aging does not necessarily force a mead into the Experimental Mead style unless the barrel has another characteristic (such as bourbon) in addition to the wood. No mead can be “out of style” for this category unless it fits into another existing mead category.  This mead should exhibit the character of all of the ingredients in varying degrees, and should show a good blending or balance between the various flavor elements.  Whatever ingredients are included, the result should be identifiable as a honey-based fermented beverage.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
examples: Moonlight Utopian, Hanssens/Lurgashall Mead the Gueuze, White Winter Cherry Bracket, Mountain Meadows Trickster’s Treat Agave Mead

name: New World Cider
description: A New World Cider is made from culinary/table apples, with wild or crab apples often used for acidity/tannin balance. Compared to other styles in this category, these ciders are generally relatively lower in tannin and higher in acidity. “New World” references the style, not a location, as ciders in this style are also made in eastern England, Australia, Germany, etc.  A refreshing drink of some substance – not bland or watery. Sweet ciders must not be cloying. Dry ciders must not be too austere.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Varieties: Common (Winesap, Macintosh, Golden Delicious, Braeburn, Jonathan), multi-use (Northern Spy, Russets, Baldwin), crabapples, any suitable wildings.
examples: Uncle John’s Fruit House Winery Apple Hard Cider, Tandem Ciders Pretty Penny (MI), Bellwether Spyglass (NY), West County Pippin (MA), White Winter Hard Apple Cider (WI), Wandering Aengus Ciderworks Bloom (OR), Æppeltreow Appely Brut and Doux (WI).

name: English Cider
description: English Cider includes the English “West Country” plus ciders inspired by that style. These ciders are made with bittersweet and bitter-sharp apple varieties cultivated specifically for cider making. English ciders are traditionally fermented and aged in wood barrels, which adds some character; however, the barrels used are rarely new, so there is no overt wood character.  Generally dry, full-bodied, austere. Complex flavor profile, long finish.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Varieties: Kingston Black, Stoke Red, Dabinett, Porter’s Perfection, Nehou, Yarlington Mill, Major, various Jerseys, etc
examples: US: Westcott Bay Traditional Very Dry, Dry and Medium Sweet (WA), Farnum Hill Extra-Dry, Dry, and Farmhouse (NH), Wandering Aengus Oaked Dry (OR), Montana CiderWorks North Fork (MT), Bellwether Heritage (NY).  UK: Oliver’s Traditional Dry, Hogan’s Dry and Medium Dry, Henney’s Dry and Vintage Still, Burrow Hill Medium, Aspall English Imperial.

name: French Cider
description: French Cider includes Normandy styles plus ciders inspired by those styles, including ciders made by various techniques to achieve the French flavor profile. These ciders are made with bittersweet and bitter-sharp apple varieties cultivated specifically for cider making. Traditional French procedures use small amounts of salt and calcium compounds (calcium chloride, calcium carbonate) to aid the process of pectin coagulation. These compounds may be used, pre-fermentation, but in limited quantity. It is a fault if judges can detect a salty or chalky taste. The enzyme PME (pectin methyl esterase) may also be used pre-fermentation for pectin coagulation. 4 BJCP Cider Style Guidelines – 2015 Edition Note that the sweetness/gravity levels indicate an overall tendency, not a sharp delineation between English and French ciders.  Medium to sweet, full-bodied, rich.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Typically made sweet to balance the tannin levels from the traditional apple varieties.
examples: US: West County Reine de Pomme (MA) France: Eric Bordelet (various), Etienne Dupont, EtienneDupont Organic, Bellot

name: New World Perry
description: New World Perry is made from culinary/table pears.  Mild. Medium to medium-sweet. Still to lightly sparkling. Only very slight acetification is acceptable. Mousiness, ropy/oily characters are serious faults
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Varieties: Bartlett, Kiefer, Comice, Conference, etc.
examples: White Winter Paarynat (WI), Uncle John’s Fruit House Winery Perry (MI)

name: Traditional Perry
description: Traditional perry is made from pears grown specifically for that purpose rather than for eating or cooking. Many “perry pears” are nearly inedible due to high tannins; some are also quite hard. Perry pears may contain substantial amounts of sorbitol, a non-fermentable sweet-tasting compound. Hence a perry can be completely dry (no residual sugar) yet taste sweet.  Tannic. Medium to medium-sweet. Still to lightly sparkling. Only very slight acetification is acceptable.  Mousiness and ropy/oily characters are serious faults.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Varieties: Butt, Gin, Brandy, Barland, Blakeney Red, Thorn, Moorcroft, etc.
examples: US: Æppeltreow Orchard Oriole Perry (WI) France: Bordelet Poire Authentique and Poire Granit, Christian Drouin Poire UK: Oliver’s Classic, Blakeney Red, and Herefordshire Dry; Hogan’s Vintage Perry.

name: New England Cider
description: This is a cider made with characteristic New England apples for relatively high acidity, with additives to raise alcohol levels and contribute additional flavor notes.  Substantial body and character. Typically relatively dry, but can be somewhat sweet if in balance and not containing hot alcohol.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Varieties: Northern Spy, Roxbury Russet, Golden Russet, Baldwin, etc.; many traditional New England apples.
examples: Snowdrift Semi-Dry (WA), Blackbird Cider Works New England Style (NY).

name: Cider With Other Fruit
description: This is a cider with other fruits or fruit-juices added – for example, berry. This is the correct style to enter a beverage fermented from a combination of apple and pear juice.  Like a white wine with complex flavors.  The apple character must marry with the added fruit so that neither one dominates the other.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
examples: West County Blueberry-Apple Wine (MA), Bellwether Cherry Street (NY), Uncle John’s Fruit Farm Winery Apple Cherry, Apple Blueberry, and Apricot Apple Hard Cider (MI)

name: Applewine
description: The term for this category is traditional but possibly misleading: it is simply a cider with substantial added sugar to achieve higher alcohol than a standard cider. As such it comes closer to a white wine than any other style. No fruit other than apples may be used in this style.  Typically like a dry white wine, balanced, and with low astringency and bitterness.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
examples: Uncle John’s Fruit House Winery Fruit House Apple (MI), McClure’s Sweet Apple Wine (IN).

name: Ice Cider
description: This is a cider style in which the juice is concentrated before fermentation either by freezing fruit before pressing or freezing juice and removing water. Fermentation stops or is arrested before reaching dryness. The character differs from Applewine in that the ice cider process increases not only sugar (hence alcohol) but acidity and all fruit flavor components proportionately. No additives are permitted in this style; in particular, sweeteners may not be used to increase gravity. This style originated in Quebec in the 1990s.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
ingredients: Varieties: Usually North American classic table fruit such as McIntosh or Cortland.
examples: US: various from Eden Ice Cider Company and Champlain Orchards. Canada: Domaine Pinnacle, Les Vergers de la Colline, and Cidrerie St-Nicolas (Quebec)

name: Cider with Herbs/Spices
description: This is a cider with any combination of “botanicals” added. Hopped ciders are included in this category. Other examples are ciders with “apple pie” spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice), ginger, lemon grass, herbal tea blends, etc.  Like a white wine with complex flavors. The apple character must marry with the botanicals and give a balanced result.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
examples: Colorado Cider Grasshop-ah (CO), Wandering Aengus Anthem Hops (OR)

name: Specialty Cider/Perry
description: This is an open-ended category for cider or perry with other ingredients such that it does not fit any of the categories above.  This includes the use of other sweeteners. A cider with added honey may be entered here if the cider character remains dominant; otherwise it should be entered as mead in the cyser sub-category. Examples also include wood-fermented or aged ciders in which the wood/barrel character is a significant part of the overall flavor profile.
profile: OG, SRM and ABV will vary.
examples: Finn River Fire Barrel (WA)

name: Cabernet Franc
description: Cabernet France is medium-bodied red wine that most likely originated in France. Known for its bell pepper-like flavors, medium-high acidity and is an ideal food pairing wine.
profile: Aromas: raspberries and plums, sometimes has leafy, herbaceous notes. With low to medium alcohol and tannins, it tempers higher alcohol content and bigger tannins.
ingredients: Known for being fermented and bottled in its own style, the Cabernet Franc grape is often blended in the popular "Bordeaux Blends".
examples: Calcu Cabernet Franc, Lang and Reed Cabernet Franc, Cosentino the Franc, Maxville Cabernet Franc

name: Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Cabernet Sauvignion is full-bodied wine with a medium level of acidity that pairs extremely well with food. It is a red grape varietal known for its thick, durable skin, and the vine’s resistance to the elements. This wine is dry (not sweet), and most people note that their mouth dries out while drinking which is due to the level of tannins present from the grape.
profile: Aroma:  green pepper, tobacco, cassis, and dark fruits such as cherries, along with a hint of vanilla that comes from aging in oak.
ingredients: Though the cabernet sauvignon grape is generally used to ferment and bottle its own style, it is well known for being blended with Merlot grapes to created the popular "Bordeaux Blend".
examples: Luc Pirlet Cabernet Sauvignon, Duckhorn Cabernet, Chateau Ste Michelle, Coastline Cabernet

name: Chardonnay
description: Chardonnay is the world's most popular grape for producing white wine.  It is one of the easiest grapes to grow as it can adapt and ripen in almost any type of terroir. It is easy for winemakers to influence the final product, so there is a wide variety of stylisitic differences possible with this  grape.
profile: Aroma - Chardonnay can range from flavors of green apples, pears, smokey, citrus, rocky and mineral driven, steely or tropical honeyed fruit in nature.  The range of styles comes primarily from the terroir it is planted in.  The type of vessel used for aging also plays a major role in the final character and style.
ingredients: Most of the time, Chardonnay grapes are used to make 100% Chardonnay wines.  However, because of its versatility, it can occasionally be used as a blending grape. May be heavily oaked to unoaked depending on preference.
examples: Clos du Bois Chardonnay, Kendall-Jackson Chardonnay, Robert Mondavi Chardonnay, Drouhin Chardonnay Laforet

name: Gewurztraminer
description: Gewürztraminer can be made in many styles and for many purposes. It can range from dry, to sweet, to fortified to sparkling. It can also be used for blending. Gewürztraminer has a tendency toward higher sugars and lower acids with high pH counts and these balances must be monitored.
profile: Aroma: Lychee, Grapefruit, Pineapple, Peach, Apricot, Orange, Cantaloupe, Rose, Honey, Ginger, Incense, Allspice, Cinnamon, Smoke
ingredients: Gewurztraminer grapes are used primarily to produce 100% Gewurztraminer wines
examples: Hugel Gewurztraminer, Chateau Ste Michelle Gewurztraminer, Pierre Sparr Gewurztraminer, Schieferkopf Gewurztraminer

name: Zinfandel
description: Zinfandel is grown primarily in Southern Italy and California. A robust red wine that is not quite as popular as its rose sister "White Zinfandel".  Grapes may be used ot produce many styles of wines.  'Old Vine' Zinfandel is particularly prized.
profile: A robust red wine. A hint of eucaluptus along with cherry, black currant, spice, other berry flavors depending on region.
ingredients: Feremented and bottled in its own style, though also often blended with other grapes to produce blends.
examples: Carlisle Rossi Ranch Zinfandel, Armida Parmelee-Hill Vinyard Zinfandel, Opolo Mountain Zinfandel

name: Merlot
description: Merlot is the second most popular red grape in America.  It is a medium-bodied red wine known for being an easy drinking red that goes well both with food as well as its own.
profile: Aroma: black fruits such as black cherry, blackberry, cassis,  truffle, violet, plum, chocolate
ingredients: Although well known fermented and bottled in its own style, the Merlot grape is widely used as a blending varietal, specifically in Bordeaux Blends.
examples: Emmolo Merlot, Whitehall Lane Merlot, Mayacamas Merlot, Robert Mondavi Napa Merlot

name: Muscat (Moscato)
description: The Muscat grape is possibly the oldest known grape variety in the world. It has been cultivated in the Mediterranean region for over 3000 years. Muscat grapes come in a variety of colors: red, pale green, pale yellow, golden, pink, brown, black and variations in between. These grapes prefer a warm climate and seem to do best in damp, deep soils.
profile: Muscat is the only grape to produce wine with the same taste and aroma as the grape itself. Have a musky aroma, sweet honeyed flavor and rich fruit and floral notes
ingredients: Even though there are around 200 varieties of Muscat grapes, only a few are considered to be suitable for making wine. Most of the Muscat wines are made from four major varieties:  Muscat Blancs a Petits Grains, Muscat of Alexandria, Muscat Ottonel, Hamburg Muscat
examples: Stella Rosa Platinum, Don Rodolfo Moscato, St Supery Moscato, Bodegas BotaniMoscato

name: Tempranillo
description: The dominant red greape in Rioja, Spain and the 4th largest planted in terms of acreage.  The name comes from the Spanish word "temprano" or early, as this greape ripens early in the season.  It is a very old variety dating back as much as 3,000 years.
profile: Flavors of dried fig, cherry, tobacco, cedar and dill.  Age has a large impact - it will be fresh and fruity early on but take on dust, tobacco and leather flavors with oak as it ages.
ingredients: It is the main grape used in several of Spains wine regions and often made as a single varietal.  It is occasionally blended as well.
examples: Local names include: Cencibel, Tinto del Pais, Tinto fino, Tinta del Toro.  Examples: Finca Alende Gaminde Single Vineyard Estate, Valderiz Ribera del Duero

name: Pinot Grigio (Pinot Gris)
description: Pinot grigio is one of the darkest skinned grapes producing white wine. The grape is found in regions all over the world, and flavors and aromas vary greatly from region to region.
profile: Aroma - A dry white whine with a punchy acidity and flavors of lemons, green apples, pears, sweet spices and honeysuckle.  Most winemakers avoid obvious oak flavor in this type of wine.  Pinot grapes are naturally low in acidity and high in sugar so the finest Pinot Grigio wines comes from cooler regions.
ingredients: The Pinot Grigio grape is primarily used to make 100% Pinot Grigio wines, however it will occasionally be used in a blend.
examples: Ecco Domani Pinot Grigio, Chateau Ste Michelle Pinot Gris, Clos du Bois Pinot Grigio

name: Pinot Noir (Burgundy)
description: Pinot Noir is a black grape that grows best in cooler environments, which contributes to crisp acidity.  Generally speaking, tannins are lower and acids are higher than in most other reds, the fruits are high-toned and red, and there is often a floral component to both the aroma and flavors.  This category also includes traditional Burgundy made from 100% Pinot Noir.
profile: Aroma:  delicate, sometimes sour, cherry and strawberry flavors with some spice.  Medium to low acidity and relatively light tannins. Oaked versions may also have smoke, vanilla and toast flavors.
ingredients: Pinot Noir grapes are primarily fermented and bottled in their own style. Winemakers rarely blend it, though Pinot Noir grapes are a key component in Champagne and other sparkling wines.  Pinot Noir is traditionall the primary grape for Burgundy.
examples: Erath Pinot Noir, Muirwood Pinot Noir, Josh Cellars Pinot Noir, Goldeneye Pinot Noir

name: Riesling
description: The Reisling varietal originated in Germany and is one of the world's most popular sweet white wines.  Most Riesling are on the sweeter end of the spectrum to balance out the high acidity, though dry Rieslings have risen in popularity.
profile: Aroma: apricot, nectarine, peach, apple, pear, pineapple, lime, Meyer lemon, honey, honeycomb, beesxwax, petrol, ginger, citrus blossom, rubber, diesel fuel.
ingredients: Rarely made with oak or blended with other grapes, the Riesling grape is fermented and bottled primarily on its own.
examples: Chateau Ste Michelle Riesling, Blue Vin Riesling, Bridgeman Riesling, Funf Riesling

name: Sangiovese (Chianti)
description: Chianti's tend to be very earthy and rustic, high in tannins, has a smell and taste of cherry and strawberry, and is high in acidity.  Pairs very well with food.
profile: Aroma: Red Fruits, Bitter Herbs, Balsamic Vinegar, Smoke, Preserved Sour Cherries, Dried Oregano, Aged Sweet Balsamic, Dry Salami, Espresso, Sweet Tobacco
ingredients: While most Chiantis are 100% Sangiovese, some winemakers like to blend the Sangiovese with a little Cabernet, Merlot or Syrah to soften it. (To be considered a Chianti, it must be made with at least 80% Sangiovese grapes).
examples: Castello Di Gabbiano Chianti, Luiano Chianti Classico, Monsanto Chianti Classico, Cecchi Natio Chianti

name: Sauvignon Blanc
description: Sauvignon Blanc is one of the most popular white wines in the U.S.  It is known for its refreshing crispness, which is due to its high levels of acidity and low amounts of sugar.
profile: A refreshing dry wine with great minerality, aromas and tastes of herbs and grasses and a crisp pucker. This wine is hardly ever aged in oak, with winemakers preferring to exhibit the bright and fruity characteristics of the grape.
ingredients: The Sauvignon grape is known well for its use in Bordeaux blends, but is also fermented and bottled on its own.
examples: Duckhorn Sauvignon Blanc, Kendall Jackson Sauvignon Blanc, Chateau Montet Sauvignon Blanc

name: Syrah (Shiraz)
description: Syrah grapes make some of the darkest most full-bodied wines in the world.  Syrahs from Italy and France tend to have more acidity and earthy-herbaceous aromas. Syrah wines from Australia, The U.S. and South America usually have more fruit-driven characteristics with lots of spice.
profile: Aroma: Blackberry, Blueberry and Boysenberry, Olive, pepper, clove, vanilla, mint, licorice, chocolate, allspice, rosemary, cured meat, bacon fat, tobacco, herbs and smoke
ingredients: While Syrah's are known for being fermented and bottled in their own style, they are frequently blended with lighter grapes to create more well-founded blends.
examples: Milton Park Shiraz, Terra Barossa Shiraz, Rosemount Shiraz, Jip Jip Rocks Shiraz

name: Grenache
description: One of the most widely grown red wine grapes produced worldwide. Requires hot dry conditions. Wines made from Grenache often lack acid, tannins and color and are frequently blended with Syrah, Termpranillo or other varieties.
profile: Spicy, red fruit flavors of raspberry and strawberry with a slight white pepper note. Prone to oxidation and browning.  Sometimes lacking in tannins, acidity and color.
ingredients: While single varietal Grenache wines are produced, it is not uncommon to blend Grenache with other varieties like Syrah, Tempranillo and Cinsaut to provide additional acidity and tannis.
examples: Denner Grenache, Samsara Grenache, Larner Vineyard Grenache, Paxton Grenache

name: Malbec
description: The prize grape of Argentina, Malbec is a full-bodied red wine whose grapes add color, tannin and spicy characteristics, producing deep colored, rich wines with freshness, balanced acidity, and flavors of plum and blackberry.
profile: Aroma: Black cherry, Pomengranate, Plum, Raspberry, Blackberry, Blueberry, Cocoa, Milk Chocolate, Coffee, Mocha, Molasses, Leather, Black Pepper, Green Stem, Gravel, Tobacco
ingredients: Feremented and bottled in its own style, also frequently used to blend in Bordeaux.
examples: Catena Alta Malbec, Alamos Malbec, Altigal Uno Malbec, Tilia Malbec

name: Nebbiolo (Barolo)
description: Nebbiolo is an Italian grape primarily from the Piedmont region. It is used in the legendary Barolo style though also often blended with other varieties to reduce its sharp tannins.  It is a very tannic grape that can take years to age.
profile: Highly tannic. Produces lightly colored red wines that have scents of tar and roses.  After aging it takes on an orange hue and has flavors like herbs, cherries, raspberries, truffles, tobacco, prunes, and violets.
ingredients: Used 100% in Barolo though this grape is also often blended with others to moderate its tannins.  Some producers may blend in some Barbera, Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Syrah now.
examples: Gaja Cost Russi Grappa Di Nebbiolo, Casca Sorba Nebbiolo D'Alba, Umberto Fiore Gattinara

name: Viognier
description: A full bodied white wine that originated in Southern France.  Known for its perfumed aromas and wide range of tastes.  Generally made as a dry wine, Viogniers are almost always noted for an oily sensation on the middle of the tongue.
profile: Aroma: ranges from tangerine, mango and honeysuckle, to vanilla with spices of nutmeg and clove. Can range in intensity from light and spritzy to bold and creamy.
ingredients: Although the Viognier grape is most often used to ferment its own bottles, it is also often used in red wine blends.
examples: Oak Grove Viognier, Sobon Estates Viognier, Cline Viognier, Horton Tower Series Viognier

name: Bordeaux Red
description: Red Bordeaux is used to differntiate from other blends made int the region.  Some of the most expensive wines in the world. Cabernet Sauvignon dominates the blends on the left bank of the Gironde and Merlot dominates the right bank.
profile: Medium to full bodied red eith earthiness and mineral or graphite notes.  Slightly fruity with a minimal influence of oak. Often has aroma and flavor of black currant, plum, cedar, violet.  Tannins are often high enough to allow aging for decades.
ingredients: The wine is made from a blend of grapes including Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot, Petit Verdot, and Malbec.
examples: Top chateaus: St Estephe, Pauillac, St Julien, Margaux, Pomeraol, St Elilion.  Sold under a complex classification system.

name: Other Red Varietal
description: This category includes red varital wine made from a single variety of red grape. This includes any red varietal grape not covered by another category. The wine maker should specify the grape variety used so it can be evaluated on that basis.
profile: A balanced red wine that relfects the character, terrior and flavor of the underlying grape variety.
ingredients: Any single variety of red wine grape not covered by another category.
examples: Varies.

name: Amarone
description: Amarone is a rich Italian dry red wine in the province of Verona, Italy.  Made from concentrated dry grapes it has a high alcohol content and is rich and unique.  It is typically aged a minimum of 5 years.
profile: A bold, ripe, raisiny full bodied red wine with little acidity.  Alcohol often is over 15%. It is tannic, but not harsh.  Rich and slightly sweet with nutty flavors.
ingredients: A blend of 45-95% Corvina (or Corvinone), 5-30% Rondinella, and other approved red grape varieties.  The grapes are dried, often on straw mats which concentrates the juices, and metabolizes acids within the skin to give a unique balance.
examples: Zeni Nino Zeni Amarone Della Valpolicella, Mago Amarone Della Valpolicella, La Guaite Di Noemi Amarone

name: Petite Sirah
description: Petite Sirah is named for the small size of the berries, yet is one of the biggest, most powerful and tannic wines produced in America.  This makes a powerful, fruity, hardy, and dense wine that pairs perfectly with a wide variety of dishes.
profile: Aroma: black pepper, blackberries, blueberries, spice and licorice
ingredients: Most often used in 100% Petit Sirah wines, but will also be blended with lighter grapes to add structure and color.
examples: Stags Leap Winery Petite Sirah, The Crusher Petite Sirah, Spellbound Petite Sirah, Bogle Petite Sirah

name: Rioja Red
description: Rioja is a region in Spain.  The term Rioja describes a particular blend of red wines from Rioja. It carries various designations depending on the age of the wine, and is often aged on American oak.  Many examples are age worthy.
profile: A big wine high in tannins.  Reflects oak aging, usually on American oak, with hints of vanilla. Caramel, coffee, roasted nuts.  Rich, notes of tobacco, cinnamon and rich fruit like cherries, blackberries and spice flavors.
ingredients: The base grape usually consistes of Tempranillo.  Grenachea (Grenache), Mazeuelo (Carignan) and Graciano make up the balance of the wine blend, along with occasionally Cabernet Sauvignon.
examples: La Rioja Alta Grana Reserva, Marques de Riscal Reserva, Bodegas Faustino I Gran Reserva

name: Super Tuscan
description: Super Tuscan is a term coined in the 1980's for a red blend from Tuscany. It blends Italian grapes with those not indigenous to Italy.  It was originally done in defiance to slowly changing wine laws, but was officially sanctioned in 1992 with a new IGT.
profile: They do vary in profiles, but most reflect both their Italian root in Sangiovese, the grape used to make Chianti.  It is a full bodied red featuring spice, dark fruit flavors like cherries and plum as well as slight tobacco leaf flavors.
ingredients: Usually a blend of tannic Sangiovese with non-indigenous grapes like Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Syrah and Cabernet Franc.
examples: Tenuta San Guido Sassicaia, Tiganello, Marchesi Antinori's Solaia, Ornellaia, Masseto

name: Priorat
description: Priorat is a blend from the Priorat region of Spain.  Garnacha (Grenache) and Carinena (Carignan) grapes provide the bulk of the blend. Some of the vines of the region are quite old providing a intensely flavored red-fruit driven wine.
profile: Sun dried red and black plum, black cherry, red and black currant all dominate the aroma.  Also reflect hard rock minerals of the region. Aroma of fresh wet pavement with a bit of wet clay.
ingredients: A blend of roughly 40% Garnacha (Grenache), 27% Cainena (Cariginan), 14% Cabernet Sauvignon, 12% Syrah and 6% Merlot.
examples: Finca Dofi, Alvaro Palacios, Clos Figueres, Priorat, Finca Dofi, Alvaro Palacios, Priorat

name: Meritage Red
description: The Meritage association was formed by a small group of Sonoma and Napa Valley vintners.  A bordeaux styl of wine blended in the US.  Typically a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Petit Verdot and Malbec.  The name "meritage" is licensed by the Mertage alliance.
profile: Bordeaux style but reflecting the New World terroir. Bright fruit flavors, acidity, California fruit and earthiness, bold and silky.
ingredients: Blended in the traditional Bordeaux-style. Must contain at least two Bordeaux grapes from the following varietals: cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc, merlot, malbec and petit verdot.
examples: Palazzo ‘Right Bank’ Red Wine, Jason Stephens Estate Meritage, Sola Meritage from Alexander Valley, Havens Meritage

name: Other Red Blend
description: This category incorporates other red wine blends not captured within another category.  The vintner should specify the style of blend or grapes used so it can be evaluated properly.
profile: Varies but should reflect the style of the blend if a regional or local style or alternatley the chracter of the grapes used in the blend if a unique combination.
ingredients: Two or more red grapes relfecting either the style used or character of the underlying grapes.
examples: Varies.

name: Semillon
description: A lesser known white grape (somewhat underrated). Used to blend Bordeaux Blanc it is gull bodied like Chardonnay but flavor closer to Pinot Gris or Sauvignon Blanc.
profile: Hints of lemon, green apple, pear or papaya depending on ripeness. Sometimes a lanolin/waxy finish. A rich, creamy lemon flavored wine like oaked Chardonnay.
ingredients: Often made as a single varietal of Semillon.  Ripe versions bring out more fruit flavors while less ripe examples have more acidity and are closer to Sauvignon Blanc.  When blended it is often Sauvignon Blanc or Muscadelle used (for White Bordeaux).
examples: Chateau Climens, Barsac France,Fenestra Semillon, Andis Bill Sillian Vineyard Semillon, L'Ecole No 41 Semillon,

name: Chenin Blanc
description: A French varietal grown throughout the world, most notably the Loire Valley in France. Varies in style depending on region from sweet to lean and acidic and dry. In France the variety is high in acidity and often used as a base for sparkling wines.  Color also varies by region.
profile: Varies from dry to sweet depending on region and ripeness. Fruity, light, acidic with hints of pear, apple, ginger, honeysuckle and quince.  Color also varies from pale straw to amber.
ingredients: Made as a varietal or often blended.  Also used as a base for many sparkling wines. May be oaked.
examples: Rococ Chenin Blanc, Georges Vigouroux de Mercues Sec Chenin Blanc, Lang & Reed Chenin Blanc

name: Other White Varietal
description: This category includes white varital wine made from a single variety of grape. This includes any white varietal grape not covered by another category. The wine maker should specify the grape variety used so it can be evaluated on that basis.
profile: A balanced white wine that relfects the character, terrior and flavor of the underlying grape variety.
ingredients: Any single variety of white wine grape not covered by another category.
examples: Varies.

name: White Rioja
description: A style from the Rioja region of Spain made from white grapes including Viura. Two styles that vary by aging.  Most are released "Fresh" and just a few are aged for 7-15 years to develop a nutty, oxidative flavor.
profile: Fresh Rioja is lean and citrusy with notes of lime peel, lemon verbana, honeydew melon, tarragon and a chalky mineral notes.  Aged versions are bold, heady with roast pineapple, caramelized honey, lime, tarragon, and hazlenut.  Dry and subtly creamed.
ingredients: Dominant varieties are Viura and Malvasia grapes.  Some made from 100% Viura. Newer versions may include non-indigenous grapes.
examples: Marques de Murrieta, Reserva, Capellanía, Rioja, Abel Mendoza, Malvasiam Juan Carlos Sancha, Ad Libitum Maturana Blanca

name: White Bordeaux
description: A blend of Semillon, Sauvignon Blanc and Muscadelle grapes. There are two styles: Rich/Creamy or Light/Fruity, with the light/fruity being the majority of the production.
profile: The light/fruity style makes up the majority and it has hints of grapefruit, lime, gooseberry, grass, honey and honeysuckle.  The rich/creamy style has hints of apples, creme brulee, ginger, orange peel and chamomile.
ingredients: A typical blend might be 53% Semillon, 38% Sauvignon Blanc, 6% Muscadelle, and 3% other.
examples: Domaine de Chevalier Blanc, Chateau Guiraud G Bordeaux Blanc, Voyager Estate Sauvignon Blanc-Semillon

name: White Rhone
description: Rhone style whites are made from two or more Rhone varieties including Viognier, Marsanne, Roussanne, Clairette and Bourboulenc.  Rhone-style blends are produced worldwide.
profile: Fruity, aromatic wines with richly scented fruits.
ingredients: The base of many blends is still Grenache Blanc.  Made from two or more Rhone varieties including Viognier, Marsanne, Roussanne, Clairette and Bourboulenc.  Others may occasionally be used.
examples: Clos Solene Hommage Blan White, Cowhorn Marsanne-Roussanne, Domaine Patrice Magni Sensation White

name: Pinot Noir Rosé
description: A dry Rosé that combines fruity flavor and acidity.  Made from Pinot Noir grapes.
profile: Pinot Noir delivers acidity and soft aromas of watermelon, raspberry, strawberry, and crabapple. Light and delicately fruity.
ingredients: Made from Pinot Noir which can be a tempermental grape and varies by season.
examples: Banfi Pinot Noir Rosé, D'Autrefois Rose de Pinot Noir, Elk Cove Pinot Noir Rosé

name: Other White Blends
description: This category includes white blended wine. This includes any white blend not covered by another category. The wine maker should specify the grape varieties or substyle used so it can be evaluated on that basis.
profile: A balanced white wine that relfects the character, terrior and flavor of the substyle or underlying grapes.
ingredients: Any blend white wine grapes not covered by another category.
examples: Varies.

name: White Zinfandel
description: Wine Zinfandel is a sweet, pink colored Rosé made from the Zinfandel grape.  It accounts for almost 10% of wine sold in the US. It was developed by accident at Sutter Home when they had a stuck fermentation in 1975.
profile: A sweet Rosé wine.  It is sweet and fruity including hints of peach, strawberry, pears, and pineapple.  Color is light pink to medium pink.
ingredients: Made from Zinfandel grapes where the grape skins are left in contact for just a short period to provide the color.
examples: Turley White Zinfandel, Mauritson White Zinfandel, Broc Cellars Sonoma County White Zinfandel

name: Tempranillo Rosé
description: Spain is one of the largest producers of Rosé.  This Rosé is made primarily from Tempranillo grapes widely used in Rioja red wines.
profile: Fruits of raspberry and strawberry with the addition of some acidity.  Hints of greep peppercorn, watermelon, strawberry, and meaty notes.  Pale, pink hue.
ingredients: The bulk of the Rosé is composed ot Tempranillo grapes, though small amounts of other local varieties like Grehache or Graciano are added.
examples: Casado Morales Rioja Rosé, Vistas Rosé , Camp Viejo Tempranillo Rosé

name: Blended Rosé or Blush
description: A Rosé or Blush made from a blend of two or more grape varieties not covered by an existing category.  This includes many of the blended Rosé's of France, Spain, Italy and California.  The wine maker should specify the grapes used in the blend.
profile: May be dry or sweet but should reflect the character of the grapes used.
ingredients: Two or more grape varieties blended together.
examples: Varies.

name: Sangiovese Rosé
description: A dry Rosé made in Tuscany, Italy but also in California and other locations from Sangiovese grapes. Fruity flavors with some spice.
profile: Flavors of sweet cherry, wild strawberry, honeydew melon along with spices like allspice, clove and cumin. Pink to salmon in color.
ingredients: Sangiovese grapes.
examples: Tenuta Pioggio Verrano - Vale in the Rose, Riecine For Jasper Rose, Ferrari-Carano Dry Sangiovese Rosé

name: Grenache Rosé
description: A dry rosé originally from Southern France but now made in other countries.  Made from Grenache grapes.
profile: Dry wine with fruity flavors including ripe strawberry, orange, hibiscus, and hints of allspice.  Moderate to high acidity for the French versions.  A somewhat darker body and color than many other rosés.
ingredients: Grenache grapes
examples: Topa Mountain Rosé of the Grenache, Anaba Rosé of the Grenache, Chalone Rose of the Grenache

name: Other Varietal Rosé or Blush
description: A Rosé or Blush made from a single variety of grape not covered by another category.  The wine should reflect the underlying terrior and character of the grape variety used.  The wine maker should specify the varietal used for evaluation.
profile: Should reflect the charcter of the variety chosen.
ingredients: A single grape variety.
examples: Vary

name: Other Fortified or Dessert Wine
description: This category is intended to capture other fortified or dessert wines not covered by an existing style Wine makers should specify the substyle or grape varieties and method used.
profile: Varies depending on substyle or grapes used.  Flavor should reflect the substyle or varieties and methods used.
ingredients: Varies depending on substyle or grapes used.
examples: Varies.

name: Port
description: Port wine is a sweet red fortified dessert wine from Portugal.  There are several substyles including the aged Tawny Port as well as red, white and rosé versions.  This category is intended to cover the red, fortified Port styles, of which the two major ones are Ruby Red and Tawny.
profile: A deep red sweet wine. Fruit flavors include carmel, raspberry, blackberry, cinnamon and chocolate.  Aged Tawny port has a wider range of flavors including peppercorn, almond, butterscotch and graham cracker.  The younger Red Port has more berry and chocolate flavors.
ingredients: A unique blend of indigenous Portuguese grapes including Touriga Franca, Touriga Nacional, Rinta Roriz (Tempranillo), Tinta Barroca and Tinta Cao.  It is typically fortified with Brandy (around 77% ABV) to stabilize and raise the alcohol level.
examples: Warre's Vintage Port, Taylor's Vintage Port, Quinta Do Noval Nacional Vintage Port, Graham's Vintage Port

name: Sherry
description: Sherry is a fortified wine from Spain's Sherry Triangle.  Though there are many substyles, the majority of Sherry is a dry, aged white wine, though some are made sweet.  There are several categories depending on whether the sherry is aged, if it is oxidized, and use of a local yeast called Flor.
profile: Most sherry is a dry, fortified wine at 15-20% alcohol or more.  It typically has nutty notes, honey, cream, hazelnut, honey, toffee, caramel and wood notes.  Aged versions can have hints of oxidation, berries, acidity, and saltiness. Aged Sherry is wonderfly complex.
ingredients: Dry sherry starts with Palomino grapes, though sweet versions also use Pedro Ximenez and Moscatel varieties.  Most are spontaneously fermented by native yeast, and a local yeast called Flor often forms a layer on top.  They are fortified with a neutral grape spirit. They are aged in Solera often for very long periods.
examples: Bodegas Dios Baca SL NV Oxford Pedro Ximenez, Lustau NV Oloroso Don Nuno Dry Sherry, Bodegas Baron NV Xixarito Pedro Ximenez

name: Ice Wine
description: Called Eiswein, the style originated in Germany. Traditionally made from grapes left on the vine during a hard freeze, and then pressed while still frozen.  The high sugar level of the frozen grapes create a slow fermenting high gravity ice wine.  Can be quite expensive.  Made worldwide now.
profile: A lucious, richly flavored wine that includes tropical fruit flavors like pineapple and papaya, but with a backbone of acidity.  Most are pale yellow to gold in color.  Ice wines vary in alcohol content - many are less than some traditional wines.
ingredients: Varies, but popular grapes include Riesling, Gewerztraminer, Cabernet Franc, Chardonnay and Cabernet Saivignon
examples: Dr Loosen Riesling Eiswein, Nittnaus Eiswein Exquisit, Pillitteri Icewine, Weingut Nigl Eiswein

name: Cava
description: Cava is a Spanish sparkling wine made using the same method as Champagne with a secondary fermentation in bottle but with different grapes. Sweetness varies from Brut Nature to Dolce (sweet).
profile: The full spectrum from very dry to sweet are produced, though most are on the dry side.  Full of crisp apple flavors, slightly acidic and may have pear or melon notes with some floral aromatics.
ingredients: The three main grapes are macabeu, parellada and xarel-lo.  Others may be blended as well.
examples: III Lustros, Brut Nature Gran Reserva, Gramona, Celler Batlle, Gran Reserva, Brut de Brut, Turó d’En Mota, Recaredo

name: Champagne
description: A sparkling wine from the Champagne region of France.  Made using a secondary fermentation that creates carbonation. Sweetness levels vary from Extra-Brut (very dry) to Demi-Sec (sweet) and there are also Rosé variants. Champagne is associated with royalty and also celebrations.
profile: Highly carbonated, usually extremely dry and has high acidity.  Some fruitiness. Often aged "on the lees" or on the yeast, it will often have a cheese rind, toasty or biscuity finish.
ingredients: Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier are used in almost all Champagne, though small amounts of Pinot Gris, Arbane, Pinot Blanc and Petit Meslier may also be used. Rules vary by appelation.
examples: Dom Pérignon, Krug Clos du Mesnil, Ruinart Blanc de Blancs NV

name: Prosecco
description: Italy's most popular sparkling wine. An Italian sparkling white wine which vary from brut to dry made from Prosecco (Glera) grapes via the Charmat (aka Tank) sparkling method. Unlike Champagne it goes through a secondary fermentation in stainless tanks and not on the lees.
profile: A very drinkable sparkling wine. Prosecco is fruity and flowery with notes of tropical fruit, hazelnut, vanilla and banana cream.  It is not quite as highly carbonated as Champagne but still has a carbonation level of about twice that of beer.
ingredients: Made from Glera (Prosecco) grapes but other indigenous grapes may also be included.
examples: Collalto Prosecco Di Conegliano Valdobbiadene Brut. La Gioiosa DOCG Prosecco Italy, Aldi Valdobbiadene Prosecco Spumante Superiore NV

name: Berry Fruit Wine
description: Fruit wine made from berry fruits. The tannin and acidity of dark berries hold up well during fermentation and provide a red wine like finish for many berries.
profile: Varies according to the fruit used.  Wine should reflect the flavors and character of the fermented fruit.
ingredients: Made from one or more berries.  Berries such as Raspberries, Blackberries, Black Currants, Elderberries, Loganberries, Gooseberriees, and others perform well. Some examples are served sparkling.
examples: Varies - many are home mads.

name: Other Sparkling Wine
description: This style includes other sparkling wine styles and sub-styles that are not covered by an existing style.  The wine maker should specify the sub-style of sparkling wine if known.
profile: Varies depending on substyle and grapes used.  Should reflect the character of the substyle or grape varieties and methods used.
ingredients: Varies.
examples: Varies.

name: Stone Fruit Wine
description: Wine made from stone fruits including plums, peaches, and tart cherries.  Wine maker should specify the fruit used and wine should reflect the charcter of the fermented fruits.
profile: Varies according to the fruit used.  Wine should reflect the flavors and character of the fermented fruit.
ingredients: Examples include peaches, plums, tart cherries, nectarines, mangoes, cherries.
examples: Vary - many are home made.

name: Madeira
description: Madeira is a fortified dry to sweet wine that takes it's name from a small island in the Atlantic Ocean.  It is made by repeatedly heating the wine giving interesting caramel, nut and toffee notes. The single varietal examples are the most prized and often aged to 20 years.
profile: Acidic from the volcanic soil. May vary from dry to sweet depending on substyle, though dry has some sweetness. Rich, earthy flavors of red fruit, prach, honey, molassas and spices.  Like other fortified and aged wines it often has a complex flavor profile.
ingredients: Inexpensive Madeira is blended but the best is made from a single varietal of one of these four grapes: Sercial, Verdelho, Boal, and Malmsey.  Unlike other wines, Madeira is heated to 40-50 C and cooled dozens of times and often exposed to oxygen.  Fortified early or late depending on sweetness desired, and sometimes fortified again before bottling.
examples: Blandy's Sercial Madeira, Coassart Gordon Bual Madeira, V. Sattui NV Madeira

name: Other Fruit Wine
description: Wine made from other fruits not covered by an existing style.  Wine maker should specify the fruit used.
profile: Varies accouding to the fruit used.  Character should reflect the color and flavor of the fermented fruit.
ingredients: Examples include tropical fruits, pineapple, rose hip wine, citric fruits, oranges, dandelion wine.
examples: Vary - many are home made.

name: Apple Wine
description: Apple wine is distinguished from cider by the higher alcohol content.  Usually sugar or another fermentable is required to raise the alcohol levels up to wine levels as apple juice typically has too low a sugar content alone.
profile: Clean finish but crisp flavor reflecting the underlying apple variety used.  Tart cider apples can produce some of the most interesting examples.
ingredients: Apples.  Some are blended. Tart cider making apples can produce some of the more interesting apple wines if you can find them.  Usually sugar is required to raise the alcohol levels to wine level as apple juice alone rarely has enough sugar content.
examples: Varies - many are home made.

name: American Barley Wine
description: Colour may range from light amber to medium copper; may rarely be as dark as light brown. Often has ruby highlights. Moderately-low to large off-white to light tan head; may have low head retention. May be cloudy with chill haze at cooler temperatures, but generally clears to good to brilliant clarity as it warms. The colour may appear to have great depth, as if viewed through a thick glass lens. High alcohol and viscosity may be visible in “legs” when beer is swirled in a glass. Aroma: Very rich and intense maltiness. Hop character moderate to assertive and often showcases citrusy or resiny American varieties (although other varieties, such as floral, earthy or spicy English varieties or a blend of varieties, may be used). Low to moderately strong fruity esters and alcohol aromatics. Malt character may be sweet, caramelly, bready, or fairly neutral. However, the intensity of aromatics often subsides with age. No diacetyl.  Flavour: Strong, intense malt flavour with noticeable bitterness. Moderately low to moderately high malty sweetness on the palate, although the finish may be somewhat sweet to quite dry (depending on aging). Hop bitterness may range from moderately strong to aggressive. While strongly malty, the balance should always seem bitter. Moderate to high hop flavour (any variety). Low to moderate fruity esters. Noticeable alcohol presence, but sharp or solventy alcohol flavours are undesirable. Flavours will smooth out and decline over time, but any oxidized character should be muted (and generally be masked by the hop character). May have some bready or caramelly malt flavours, but these should not be high. Roasted or burnt malt flavours are inappropriate. No diacetyl. Mouthfeel: Full-bodied and chewy, with a velvety, luscious texture (although the body may decline with long conditioning). Alcohol warmth should be present, but not be excessively hot. Should not be syrupy and under-attenuated. Carbonation may be low to moderate, depending on age and conditioning.
profile: A well-hopped American interpretation of the richest and strongest of the English ales. The hop character should be evident throughout, but does not have to be unbalanced. The alcohol strength and hop bitterness often combine to leave a very long finish.
ingredients: Well-modified pale malt should form the backbone of the grist. Some specialty or character malts may be used. Dark malts should be used with great restraint, if at all, as most of the colour arises from a lengthy boil. Citrusy American hops are common, although any varieties can be used in quantity. Generally uses an attenuative American yeast.
examples: Sierra Nevada Bigfoot, Rogue Old Crustacean, Anchor Old Foghorn, Victory Old Horizontal, Avery Hog Heaven Barleywine, Bell’s Third Coast Old Ale, Three Floyds Behemoth, Stone Old Guardian, Bridgeport Old Knucklehead, Hair of the Dog Doggie Claws

name: American Brown Ale
description: Light to very dark brown colour. Clear. Low to moderate off-white to light tan head. Aroma: Malty, sweet and rich, which often has a chocolate, caramel, nutty and/or toasty quality. Hop aroma is typically low to moderate. Some interpretations of the style may feature a stronger hop aroma, a citrusy American hop character, and/or a fresh dry- hopped aroma (all are optional). Fruity esters are moderate to very low. The dark malt character is more robust than other brown ales, yet stops short of being overly porter-like. The malt and hops are generally balanced. Moderately low to no diacetyl. Flavour: Medium to high malty flavour (often with caramel, toasty and/or chocolate flavours), with medium to medium-high bitterness. The medium to medium-dry finish provides an aftertaste having both malt and hops. Hop flavour can be light to moderate, and may optionally have a citrusy character. Very low to moderate fruity esters. Moderately low to no diacetyl. Mouthfeel: Medium to medium-full body. More bitter versions may have a dry, resiny impression. Moderate to moderately high carbonation. Stronger versions may have some alcohol warmth in the finish.
profile: Can be considered a bigger, maltier, hoppier interpretation of Northern English brown ale or a hoppier, less malty Brown Porter, often including the citrus-accented hop presence that is characteristic of American hop varieties.
ingredients: Well-modified pale malt, either American or Continental, plus crystal and darker malts should complete the malt bill. American hops are typical, but UK or noble hops can also be used. Moderate carbonate water would appropriately balance the dark malt acidity.
examples: Brooklyn Brown Ale, Great Lakes Cleveland Brown Ale, Avery Ellie’s Brown Ale, Left Hand Deep Cover Brown Ale, Bell’s Best Brown, North Coast Acme Brown, Lost Coast Downtown Brown, Big Sky Moose Drool Brown Ale

name: American IPA
description: Colour ranges from medium gold to medium reddish copper; some versions can have an orange-ish tint. Should be clear, although unfiltered dry-hopped versions may be a bit hazy. Good head stand with white to off-white colour should persist.  Aroma: A prominent to intense hop aroma with a citrusy, floral, perfume-like, resinous, piney, and/or fruity character derived from American hops. Many versions are dry hopped and can have an additional grassy aroma, although this is not required. Some clean malty sweetness may be found in the background, but should be at a lower level than in English examples. Fruitiness, either from esters or hops, may also be detected in some versions, although a neutral fermentation character is also acceptable. Some alcohol may be noted. Flavour: Hop flavour is medium to high, and should reflect an American hop character with citrusy, floral, resinous, piney or fruity aspects. Medium-high to very high hop bitterness, although the malt backbone will support the strong hop character and provide the best balance. Malt flavour should be low to medium, and is generally clean and malty sweet although some caramel or toasty flavours are acceptable at low levels. No diacetyl. Low fruitiness is acceptable but not required. The bitterness may linger into the aftertaste but should not be harsh. Medium-dry to dry finish. Some clean alcohol flavour can be noted in stronger versions. Oak is inappropriate in this style. May be slightly sulfury but most examples do not exhibit this character. Mouthfeel: Smooth, medium-light to medium-bodied mouthfeel without hop-derived astringency, although moderate to medium- high carbonation can combine to render an overall dry sensation in the presence of malt sweetness. Some smooth alcohol warming can and should be sensed in stronger (but not all) versions. Body is generally less than in English counterparts.
profile: A decidedly hoppy and bitter, moderately strong American pale ale.
ingredients: Pale ale malt (well-modified and suitable for single- temperature infusion mashing); American hops; American yeast that can give a clean or slightly fruity profile. Generally all-malt, but mashed at lower temperatures for high attenuation. Water character varies from soft to moderately sulfate. Versions with a noticeable Rye character should be entered in the Specialty category.
examples: Stone IPA, Victory Hop Devil, Anderson Valley Hop Ottin’, Anchor Liberty Ale, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Three Floyds Alpha King, Harpoon IPA, Bell’s Two-Hearted Ale, Avery IPA, Founder’s Centennial IPA, Mendocino White Hawk Select IPA

name: American Pale Ale
description: Pale golden to deep amber. Moderately large white to off-white head with good retention. Generally quite clear, although dry-hopped versions may be slightly hazy. Aroma: Usually moderate to strong hop aroma from dry hopping or late kettle additions of American hop varieties. A citrusy hop character is very common, but not required. Low to moderate maltiness supports the hop presentation, and may optionally show small amounts of specialty malt character (bready, toasty, biscuity). Fruity esters vary from moderate to none. No diacetyl. Dry hopping (if used) may add grassy notes, although this character should not be excessive. Flavour: Usually a moderate to high hop flavour, often showing a citrusy American hop character (although other hop varieties may be used). Low to moderately high clean malt character supports the hop presentation, and may optionally show small amounts of specialty malt character (bready, toasty, biscuity). The balance is typically towards the late hops and bitterness, but the malt presence can be substantial. Caramel flavours are usually restrained or absent. Fruity esters can be moderate to none. Moderate to high hop bitterness with a medium to dry finish. Hop flavour and bitterness often lingers into the finish. No diacetyl. Dry hopping (if used) may add grassy notes, although this character should not be excessive. Mouthfeel: Medium-light to medium body. Carbonation moderate to high. Overall smooth finish without astringency often associated with high hopping rates.
profile: Refreshing and hoppy, yet with sufficient supporting malt.
ingredients: Pale ale malt, typically American two-row. American hops, often but not always ones with a citrusy character. American ale yeast. Water can vary in sulfate content, but carbonate content should be relatively low. Specialty grains may add character and complexity, but generally make up a relatively small portion of the grist. Grains that add malt flavour and richness, light sweetness, and toasty or bready notes are often used (along with late hops) to differentiate brands.
examples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Stone Pale Ale, Great Lakes Burning River Pale Ale, Full Sail Pale Ale, Three Floyds X-Tra Pale Ale, Anderson Valley Poleeko Gold Pale Ale,

name: Australian Bitter Ale
description: Amber to pale copper; bright clarity; moderate white head supported by very high carbonation. Aroma: Light fruity esters with a background caramel note. Hop aroma low to none. No diacetyl. Flavour: Moderately fruity, with a light caramel malt flavour. A distinctive peppery, herbaceous note from Pride of Ringwood hops should be noticed. Malty sweetness should be low, tipping the balance firmly towards bitterness, without being aggressively bitter. Medium-dry finish, with a predominantly fruity/bitter aftertaste. Trace fusels/phenols from high sucrose fermentation may contribute a “tangy” flavour note, often considered characteristic of Australian style beer. If present this character should not be perceived as sharp or solventy. Mouthfeel: Light to medium-light body, with a noticeable carbonation prickle, particularly when served chilled.
profile: A crisp, light flavoured, thirst-quenching Bitter, ideally suited to a hot climate. Traditionally served well chilled and highly carbonated, accentuating the characteristic tangy hop bitterness.
ingredients: Australian 2-row lager malt. Restrained use of crystal malt for colour and flavour. Substantial proportion of cane sugar, typically around 30%, for light body and signature fermentation profile. Pride of Ringwood hops, bittering addition only. CUB ale yeast or similar. Attenuative English or American strains most suitable. Note: Whitelabs WLP009 Australian Ale yeast (Coopers strain) is unsuitable. Variable water profile, soft Pilsen type preferred.
examples: The major Bitter Ale brand names have survived but the modern versions are all lagers and the term “Ale” has been dropped from labelling (eg. Victoria Bitter, Melbourne Bitter, Castlemaine XXXX Bitter, Toohey’s Red Bitter, West End Bitter, Emu Bitter, Cascade Bitter, Boags Strongarm Bitter).

name: Australian Dark/Old Ale
description: Mid-brown to dark brown, sometimes almost black and opaque. Low to medium carbonation. Excessive carbonation or flatness should be penalized. Aroma: Mild malt aroma, with low to moderate fruitiness and toasty or light roasty notes. No to low hop aroma, caramel or diacetyl. Any yeasty notes or phenolics should be penalized, as should any excessive fruitiness or sweet caramel characters. Slight chocolate is acceptable. Clean aroma is essential. Flavour: Mild maltiness with no hop flavour or diacety. Low to moderate fruitiness, light roastiness can be evident. Dry maltiness on the finish. Clean and quaffable. Low to medium carbonation. Any phenolics, diacetyl, yeasty flavours, astringency, harshness, or noticeable sweetness or alcohol, should be penalized. Mouthfeel: Light to medium body. Low to medium carbonation.
profile: A dry, mildly flavoured session beer. Malt evident but evenly balanced by hop bitterness.
ingredients: Pale and chocolate malt, clean bittering hop such as Pride of Ringwood
examples: Toohey’s Old Ale

name: Australian Pale Ale
description: Best examples will display good clarity, gold to amber colour, with a persistent snow white head supported by brisk carbonation from bottle conditioning. Aroma: Fruity yeast-derived aromas most prominent, with light, sweet pale malt underneath. Hop aroma low to none. No diacetyl. Flavour: Medium to high fruitiness, often pear-like. Supported by light, bready pale malt flavour. Caramel malt flavours out of style. Banana ester from high fermentation temperature may be noticed,  but should not dominate. A mild but distinctive peppery, herbaceous flavour from Pride of Ringwood hops is desirable. Medium to high bitterness - may be higher in historical versions, but not crude or harsh. Long dry finish from extremely high attenuation, with a balanced fruity aftertaste. Body & Mouthfeel: Light to medium-light body - any impression of palate fullness from residual dextrins should be penalized. Clean, crisp mouthfeel may be enhanced by spritzy carbonation.
profile: A lively, fruity Pale Ale with surprising lightness of body, solid bitterness, and a refreshing dry finish well suited to a hot climate. Can be thought of as a “light” Burton IPA without the dry-hopping. Relies on yeast character to compensate for diminished late hop expression - bland examples lacking fruitiness should be considered out of style.
ingredients: Lightly kilned Australian 2-row pale malt, lager varieties typical. Judicious use of crystal malt for colour adjustment. Small proportion of wheat may assist head retention. No adjuncts, cane sugar for priming only. Australian hops, esp. Pride of Ringwood
examples: Coopers Sparkling Ale (5.8% ABV), Coopers Original Pale Ale (4.5% ABV)

name: Australian Premium Lager
description: Straw to pale gold. Bright, with a reasonable head. Darker than common Australian lagers, due to the use of less adjuncts. Aroma: A mild, malt aroma, which may be supported by low to moderate, and even possibly noble, hop notes. Estery fruitiness, diacetyl, and phenolic or yeasty notes should be absent. Flavour: Low to moderate mild malt flavour may be supported by low to moderate hop flavours. Bitterness can range from low- medium (lagers) to high-medium (pilsners), resulting in a neutral to slightly bitter malt/bitterness balance. Medium to medium-high carbonation. Crisp and dry. Any fruity flavours, phenolics, yeasty flavours, diacetyl, astringency or harshness, should be penalized. Mouthfeel: Light to light-medium.
profile: A clean, crisp lager, designed basically for quaffing, but containing more interest and more malt and hop character than the typical Australian session lagers.
examples: Malt Shovel Pilsner, Boags Premium Lager.

name: Australian Strong/Foreign Extra Stout
description: Very deep brown to black in colour. Clarity usually obscured by deep colour (if not opaque, should be clear). Large tan to brown head with good retention. Aroma: Roasted grain aromas moderate to high, and can have coffee, chocolate and/or lightly burnt notes. Fruitiness medium to high. Some versions may have a sweet aroma, or molasses, licorice, dried fruit, and/or vinoSimilar to dry or sweet stout, but with more gravity. Pale and dark roasted malts and grains. Hops mostly for bitterness. May use adjuncts and sugar to boost gravity. Ale yeast (although some tropical stouts are brewed with lager yeast).
profile: A very dark, moderately strong, roasty ale. Tropical varieties can be quite sweet, while export versions can be drier and fairly robust.
ingredients: Similar to dry or sweet stout, but with more gravity. Pale and dark roasted malts and grains. Hops mostly for bitterness. May use adjuncts and sugar to boost gravity. Ale yeast (although some tropical stouts are brewed with lager yeast).
examples: Tropical-Type: Lion Stout (Sri Lanka), ABC Stout (Singapore), Dragon Stout, Royal Extra “The Lion Stout” (Trinidad), Jamaica Stout, Export-Type: Guinness Extra Stout (bottled US product), Guinness Foreign Extra Stout (bottled, not sold in the US), Coopers Best Extra Stout, Freeminer Deep Shaft Stout, Sheaf Stout, Bell’s Double Cream Stout

name: Australian lager
description: Appearance: Very pale straw to pale gold colour. White head. Carbonation medium to high. Clarity good to excellent. Aroma: Little to no malt aroma. Hop aroma may range from low to none and may be flowery. Slight fruity aromas from yeast and hop varieties used may exist. No diacetyl. Flavour:. Crisp and dry flavour with some low levels of sweetness. Hop flavour may range from low to medium. Hop bitterness low to medium. Balance can vary from slightly malty to slightly bitter, but is usually close to even. No diacetyl. No fruitiness. Finish tending dry. Mouthfeel: Low to low medium. Well carbonated. Slight carbonic bite on tongue is acceptable
profile: Light, refreshing and thirst quenching.
examples: Fosters Lager, Carlton Draught, XXXX, and Tooheys New.

name: Baltic Porter
description: Dark reddish copper to opaque dark brown (not black). Thick, persistent tan-coloured head. Clear, although darker versions can be opaque. Aroma: Rich malty sweetness often containing caramel, toffee, nutty to deep toast, and/or licorice notes. Complex alcohol and ester profile of moderate strength, and reminiscent of plums, prunes, raisins, cherries or currants, occasioGenerally lager yeast (cold fermented if using ale yeast). Debittered chocolate or black malt. Munich or Vienna base malt. Continental hops. May contain crystal malts and/or adjuncts. Brown or amber malt common in historical recipes.
profile: A Baltic Porter often has the malt flavours reminiscent of an English brown porter and the restrained roast of a schwarzbier, but with a higher OG and alcohol content than either. Very complex, with multi-layered flavours.
ingredients: Generally lager yeast (cold fermented if using ale yeast). Debittered chocolate or black malt. Munich or Vienna base malt. Continental hops. May contain crystal malts and/or adjuncts. Brown or amber malt common in historical recipes.
examples: Sinebrychoff Porter (Finland), Okomin Porter (Poland), Zywiec Porter (Poland), Baltika Porter (Russia),

name: Belgian Blonde Ale
description: Light to deep gold colour. Generally very clear. Large, dense, and creamy white to off-white head. Good head retention with Belgian lace. Aroma: Light earthy or spicy hop nose, along with a lightly sweet pils malt character. Shows a subtle yeast character that may include spicy phenolics, perfumy or honey-like alcohol, or yeasty, fruity esters (commonly orange-like or lemony). Light sweetness that may have a slightly sugar-like character. Subtle yet complex. Flavour: Smooth, light to moderate pils malt sweetness initially, but finishes medium-dry to dry with some smooth alcohol becoming evident in the aftertaste. Medium hop and alcohol bitterness to balance. Light hop flavour, can be spicy or earthy. Very soft yeast character (esters and alcohols, which are sometimes perfumy or orange/lemon-like). Light spicy phenolics optional. Some candi lightly caramelised sugar or honey-like sweetness on palate. Mouthfeel: Medium-high to high carbonation, can give mouth- filling bubbly sensation. Medium body. Light to moderate alcohol warmth, but smooth. Can be somewhat creamy.
profile: A moderate-strength golden ale that has a subtle Belgian complexity, slightly sweet flavour, and dry finish.
ingredients: Belgian pils malt, aromatic malts, sugar candi sugar or sucrose, Belgian yeast strains that produce complex alcohol, phenolics and perfumy esters, noble, Styrian Goldings or East Kent Goldings hops. No spices are traditionally used, although the ingredients and fermentation by-products may give an impression of spicing (often reminiscent of oranges or lemons).
examples: Leffe Blond, Affligem Blond, La Trappe (Koningshoeven) Blond, Grimbergen Blond, Val-Dieu Blond, Straffe Hendrik Blonde, Pater Lieven Blond Abbey Ale

name: Belgian Dark Strong Ale
description: Deep amber to deep coppery-brown in colour (“dark” in this context implies “more deeply coloured than golden”). Huge, dense, moussy, persistent cream- to light tancoloured head. Can be clear to somewhat hazy. Aroma: Complex, with a rich malty sweetness, significant esters and alcohol, and an optional light to moderate spiciness. The malt is rich and strong, and can have a Munich-type quality often with a caramel, toast and/or bready aroma. The fruity esters are strong to moderately low, and can contain raisin, plum, dried cherry, fig or prune notes. Spicy phenols may be present, but usually have a peppery quality not clove-like. Alcohols are soft, spicy, perfumy and/or rose-like, and are low to moderate in intensity. Hops are not usually present (but a very low noble hop aroma is acceptable). No diacetyl. No dark/roast malt aroma. No hot alcohols or solventy aromas. No recognizable spice additions. Flavour: Similar to aroma (same malt, ester, phenol, alcohol, hop and spice comments apply to flavour as well). Moderately malty or sweet on palate. Finish is variable depending on interpretation (authentic Trappist versions are moderately dry to dry, Abbey versions can be medium-dry to sweet). Low bitterness for a beer of this strength; alcohol provides some of the balance to the malt. Sweeter and more full-bodied beers will have a higher bitterness level to balance. Almost all versions are malty in the balance, although a few are lightly bitter. The complex and varied flavours should blend smoothly and harmoniously. Mouthfeel: High carbonation but no carbonic acid “bite.” Smooth but noticeable alcohol warmth.
